citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A two-year-old male kangaroo named Thumper did not receive daily observation adequate to ensure its health and well-
being. The licensee indicated that Thumper was observed to be in good health, died suddenly on 2/11/2025, and was
submitted for necropsy on 2/11/2025. The attending veterinarian was not notified of any unhealthy conditions in Thumper,
until after his death. The necropsy report indicated that Thumper had a chronic disease condition and was very thin.
Specifically, the necropsy report identified that Thumper had extensive localized ulceration and inflammation of the skin
on both feet (focally extensive, bilateral, ulcerative pododermatitis). Second, the report showed Thumper had severe
inflammation of the forestomach (severe, multifocal, hemorrhagic and neutrophilic gastritis). Third the report showed that
Thumper was negative for Toxoplasma gondii. Finally, the report showed that Thumper has severe loss of fat and muscle
tissue (emaciation with serous atrophy of fat and diffuse muscle atrophy) indicative of chronic disease or inadequate
nutrition. Dailly observations performed by personnel at the licensed facility, failed to identify the inflammation in the feet
or the thin body condition of Thumper.
Inadequate daily observations can lead to the prolonged suffering of animals when injuries or changes in their health or
behavior are not noticed in a timely manner.
Animals must be observed daily to assess their health and well-being. In addition, there must be a mechanism of direct
and accurate information, conveyed to the attending veterinarian, on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being.
To be corrected from this day (4/11/2025) forward.

At the time of the inspection, records of acquisition, records of animals on hand (inventory), and records of disposition
were inadequate, as follows:
1) The acquisition record for a Bison shipped to the facility on 1/18/2025 did not include the USDA license number of the
facility from which the Bison was acquired.
2) The acquisition record for 3 silver pheasants obtained on 4/5/2025 did not include the street address of the
individual from whom the pheasants were obtained. In addition, the record did not include the USDA license number,
registration number, or Driver’s license and vehicle license number of the of the individual from whom the pheasants were
obtained.
3) The acquisition record for 2 swans obtained on 3/20/2025 did not include the name of the individual from whom the
swans were obtained. In addition, the record did not include the USDA license number, registration number, or Driver’s
license and vehicle license number of the of the individual from whom the swans were obtained.
4) The record of disposition for a kangaroo that died on or shortly before 2/11/2025 did not include the date of disposition.
5) The record of animals on hand (inventory) was incorrect. The following animals were not listed on the inventory:
• 1 North American black duck,
• 2 guinea fowl,
• 3 silver pheasants.
Further, the inventory was incorrect regarding the number of the following animals:
• 15 Mandrin ducks (there were 10),
• 1 reeves pheasant (there were 2),
• 11 white tail deer (there were 5),
• 7 Fallow deer (there were 8),
• 2 zebu (there were 3),
• 2 bison (there were 3).
Accurate records of animals on hand, including acquisitions and dispositions (purchases/births and sales/deaths) are
necessary to assess the health and wellbeing of the animals on site and allow tracking of animals being used for
regulatory purposes.
Records or forms must be maintained which fully and correctly disclose information concerning animals purchased or
otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in or under the control of the license, or which are transported,
sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by the licensee. The records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any
animal while in possession or under the control of the licensee. Such records or forms shall include the following: 1) The
name and address of the person from whom the animals were purchased or otherwise acquired; 2) The USDA license or
registration number of the person if he or she is licensed or registered under the Act; 3) The vehicle license number and
State, and the driver’s license number (or photographic identification card for nondrivers issued by a State) and State of
the person, if he or she is not licensed or registered under the Act; 4) The name and address of the person to whom an
animal was sold or given; 5) The date of purchase, acquisition, sale, or disposal of the animal(s); 6) The species of the
animal(s); and (7) The number of animals in the shipment.

At the time of the inspection, pools or aquatic areas for the dabbling type ducks at the facility were either absent or
inadequate for the needs of the ducks. One enclosure with 10 Mandrin ducks, 2 pintail ducks, 4 wood ducks, and 1
American black duck had three pools about 5 inches deep, 4 feet long, and 2 feet wide. Further, there were no available
pools for the 7 free ranging Muscovy ducks at the facility. The aquatic areas in the enclosures housing aquatic birds are
either absent or not sufficiently deep to allow the ducks to make normal postural and social adjustments. Inadequate
provision of aquatic areas for aquatic birds can lead to malnutrition, poor condition, debility, stress, and/or abnormal
behavioral patterns.
Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area and a dry area that allows
easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient surface area
and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and
foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the
enclosure.

At the time of the inspection, there was molded and caked feed inside the self-feeder storage hopper that provided feed
for 5 peacocks and 3 silver pheasants. A caked chunk of feed about 3 inches long and 1 inch in diameter was adhered to
one corner of the self-feeder storage hopper. In addition, a chunk of molded and caked feed about 2 inches long and 2
inch in diameter was sitting on top of the feed inside the self-feeder storage hopper. Molding and caking of feed can
decrease the palatability and nutritive value of the feed. Birds provided such deteriorated feed may lose weight or suffer
other health issues.
Measures must be taken to ensure there is no molding, deterioration, contamination, caking, wetting, freezing of food
within or on food receptacles.
To be corrected from this day (4/10/2024) forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
